reviews.text: A small but beautifully decorated bridge in the Gothic District near the Cathedral. Absolutely beautiful!
A lovely piece of gothic rennaissance architechture which is on a wonderfully  evocative road which is difficult to photograph due to the masses of tourists, try early in morning or late at night
Nice architecture. This is close to the cathedral, so make sure to visit this place when you are going there.
It reminds me of the Bridge of Sighs.  Without the canals.  Or the prison.  But it is still really neat and you will probably stumble upon it when you are wandering aroung Barcelona Cathedral.

One of the most photographed sights in Barcelona’s Gothic Quarter, El Pont del Bisbe  was built  in 1928. The bridge was designed by architect Joan Rubió I Bellver . It is one of the newest buildings in the area, but the neo-Gothic bridge is associated with several local legends and superstitions. All of the legends relate to the gruesome skull and dagger motif which decorates the underside of the bridge. A tourist spot worth visiting. Very authentic area and beautiful side streets leading on and on. Great exploration area.

The Bishop's Bridge was built for the Barcelona International Expostition of 1929.  A beautiful sight not to be missed in the Gothic Quarter.  Loved walking through the small narrow streets of this quarter.  Although it is relatively new compared to the the rest of the architecture in the Gothic Quarter it fits in easily.

We were walking around the Gothic Quarter as it was close to our hotel and came across this unique bridge to hear a walking tour guide talk of the bridge and it’s history and the lore of how if you walk under the bridge while staring at the skull beneath and make a wish it may come true
Also known as the Bishop's bridge. This is located in the Gothic quarter. We heard church bells and it totally added to the whole Gothic feel of things!
The El Pont del Bisbe is a small bridge that connects Palau de la Generalitat to La Casa dels Canonges. A very popular sight in Barcelona and I'm not surprised as it's postcard picture perfect.
This is a cute little bridge with lots of character in the middle of a small street in the heart of the Gothic Quarters.
We have stopped by observing this pont and the scenic street as part of the Barri Gothic walk on our way from Placa de Rei to Placa de Sant Jaume. Recomended to stop by!
Close to the Cathedral, easy to find; just follow the tourists! Everyone wants a picture of this bridge, linking two buildings. And a very impressive one, I must admit.

Free. 
Close to Barcelona Cathedral.
visit Duration: 15 minutes.

The bridge bears the name of Obispo Irurita, who was the bishop of Barcelona. This bridge links the Palau de la Generalitat to La Casa dels Canonges.

You will notice the Skull and dagger motif decorating the underside of the bridge. Many superstitions exist. Among them that the skull rather than being a stone carving, it is in fact a real human skull!

Another legend says that if the dagger which traverses the skull is ever removed then the city of Barcelona will be destroyed.

Another legend states that if you make a wish while walking backwards under the bridge and looking directly at the skull then that wish will come true.
There are so many places to see and do in this section of the city. I’m not exactly sure why this is so popular but that’s probably my fault. It’s right next to the Cathedral and it’s easy to find.
Bridge (walkway) between two buildings close to the Cathedral and in the Gothic area which has many interesting features.

This is a much photographed structure and dates back only to 1929 and the Barcelona International Exposition.The architect (clearly crazy) proposed that all non Gothic structures near the cathedral be torn down and replaced with new Gothic structures. His idea was rejected and only the bridge was built although he did a good job with it so my apologies for the crazy comment.This area is one of the best in Barcelona.

The Bishops Bridge was built in the 1920's in a gothic style, and despite its relative newness the craftsmanship is very intricate and beautiful, it is certainly worth a photo stop when on a walking tour of the city, it is close to the original cathedral.
So we walked around and around using google map to tracked this bridge. It took us awhile but we found it eventually. It is near the Barcelona Cathedral! So many tourists  here !

This tiny bridge is in the Gothic Quarter of the city a stones throw from the Cathedral. It is full of character and has minute and detailed craftmanship. Also, do not lose sight of the walls to it's sides as they are worth viewing up close too.

We stumbled upon this while walking through the Gothic Quarter on our way back from visiting the Basilica of Santa Maria of the Sea,  It reminded me of the Bridge of Sighs in Venice.  Just be careful, there are beggars along the street.

A lot of tour groups pass through here and when there is a crowd, it's fiesta time for pickpockets.  Be aware of your belongings when you are admiring the views - somebody will just bump into you "accidentally".  My wife was almost a victim - luckily the credit card holder in her bag is very tight.
Beautiful architecture. Lovely little side streets off the main square so full of culture. Lovely atmosphere

Beautiful gothic bridge on the walk between Placa Nova and Placa de Saint Jaume.  A regularly photographed landmark, it really is wonderful to see the detail up close and I think the best view is from Placa de Saint Jaume.

This seems to me as one of the most photographed bridge in Barcelona. I've seen it in many pictures that were posted on social media. I'm glad I passed by it and was able to see it personally. It is beautiful and a pleasure to see.

This bridge is easy to get to, located in a lovely district to just walk around and see the history.  The bridge is a popular photo spot and appeals to the romantic in all of us. 

It is often compared to the Bridge of Sighs in Venice because of its beauty and picturesque nature but moreover it isn't something you would expect to see in its location and I think that is what makes it remarkable.
Absolutely loved walking through these amazing Barcelona streets full of culture and history,  street music performance in nearly every corner which was a must see. Streets are full of life.

The Pont del Bisbe (Bishop Street Bridge) is a Gothic bridge built in 1928 and connects the House of Canons with the Palau de la Generalitat.
The decor is inspired by the forms of flamboyant Gothic and one of the most photographed sights in the Gothic Quarter of Barcelona.
You are bound to come across it whilst exploring the Gothic Quarter.
Similar to the Bridge of Sighs in Venice/Oxford.

In idyllic Barri Gotic there is a lot of very small roads.
On of them is Carrer del Bisbe, and here you find Pont del Bisbe.
It is so beautiful.
Give yourself good time to walking round in Barri Gotic
Just walk around, you will run into this pont del Bisbe in Barri Gotic. You don't have to look for this, by walking around, you will find it.

This small bridge in the Carrer Bisbe is very near the cathedral  and is built over a narrow medieval street. The area can be crowded but I was fortunate in November that the crowds had gone. Look up and you will be rewarded with a great photo op.

As you're ambling your way through the Gotic on the way to the Cathedral, you are apt to stumble upon this picturesque pedestrian bridge crossing the lane from building to building. Doges? Medici? Anyone?
A quaint little bridge in one of the narrow streets in the gothic quarter near to the cathedral, can be quite crowded though. Very pretty.
A tiny stone bridge crossing Carrer del Bisbe,between two old buildings.It's a kind of Bridge of Sighs,catalan version.Close to it is The Cathedral of Barcelona.
A nice place in the gothic area. Good to take a nice picture, the problem  is that during the day is always overcrowded.
